quoteLast: , and then halted near a creek to feed horses and get supper. At 11 o'clock, the moon having risen, were ordered forward, and soon passed through the small town of Farmington.
title: Our Battery; Or, The Journal of Company B, 1st O.V.A.
author: Cutter, O. P. (Orlando Phelps), 1824-1884

quoteFirst: Between La Chine and Montreal, the river has a very dangerous rapid, on account of which the government has built a canal as far as this place, which is nine miles long, has several locks, and is said to be of much importance to the trade. As we preferred going by land we hired a stage-coach, and started
quoteTime: about eight o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: during a violent thunder-storm. Lady Clare, who was scarcely recovered from the fear which she experienced on the water, would willingly have spent the night here in a tavern, as she was much afraid to travel during a thunder-storm at night.
title: Travels Through North America, During the Years 1825 and 1826. v. 1-2
author: Bernhard, Duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, 1792-1862

quoteLast: Judge Hascall introduced the gentlemen as his friends and neighbors from Genesee County, N. Y. They were all distinguished men, holding high positions in their several pursuits.
title: The Missing Link in Modern Spiritualism
author: Underhill, A. Leah (Ann Leah), 1814-1890

quoteFirst: For expedition's sake it was arranged that they should post, while Lady D----'s groom was to follow with her horses, she taking with herself her own maid and one male servant. They left the city when the day was considerably spent, and consequently made but three stages in the first day; upon the second, at
quoteLast: , they had reached the town of K----k, distant about fifteen miles from Castle Ardagh. Here, owing to Miss F----d's great fatigue, she having been for a considerable time in a very delicate state of health, it was determined to put up for the night.
title: The Purcell Papers — Volume 1
author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan, 1814-1873

quoteLast: he signalled to stop. Hans sat down at once. The lamps were hung upon a projection in the lava; we were in a sort of cavern where there was plenty of air.
title: A Journey into the Interior of the Earth
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Malleson, F. A. (Frederick Amadeus), 1819-1897 [Translator]

quoteFirst: 4th.--Tuesday. Pleasant. The troops and Indians crossed the river as yestirday and returned
quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the evening
title: Journal of an American Prisoner at Fort Malden and Quebec in the War of 1812
author: Reynolds, James, active 1812; Fairchild, G. M. (George Moore), 1854-1912 [Editor]

quoteLast: , and this delicious excursion, like all others, _had to end_. But the quiet old town, with its musical name and its great orchestra, will long remain in my memory.
title: Music-Study in Germany, from the Home Correspondence of Amy Fay
author: Fay, Amy, 1844-1928; Peirce, Fay, 1836- [Editor]

quoteTime: About eight o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: , the table near the stairs was generally occupied by flower-girls, dressed in dingy clothes, and brightly feathered hats. They placed their empty baskets on the floor, and shouted at their companions--men who sold newspapers, boot-laces, and cheap toys.
title: Vain Fortune: A Novel
author: Moore, George, 1852-1933; Greiffenhagen, Maurice, 1862-1931 [Illustrator]

quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the evening
title: Forgotten Tales of Long Ago
author: Lucas, E. V. (Edward Verrall), 1868-1938; Bedford, F. D., 1864-1954 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The carts had come up by this time; a leather hood was substituted for the blanket--a rather ticklish operation, during which one man was badly bitten in the hand. The cheetahs know how to use their teeth and claws. Having been securely fastened on the carts, and the nooses collected, we started for camp, which we reached
quoteLast: . I was much pleased with what I had seen and learnt, but it took me a long time to get the smell of the Vardis out of my head. The next morning I went to see the cheetahs and found that they had been tied spread-eagle fashion on the carts, and with their hoods firmly tied.
title: Natural History of the Mammalia of India and Ceylon
author: Sterndale, Robert Armitage, 1839-1902
